content: Section 233(e) of the Act is amended to allow agreements to enter into force after 60 days of transmittal to Congress, excluding certain days. Section 233(e) of the Act is amended to allow agreements to enter into force after 60 days of transmittal to Congress, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, holidays, and days when either House of Congress is not in session. Documents setting forth agreements must be delivered to both Houses of Congress on the same day and to the Clerk of the House of Representatives or the Secretary of the Senate if either House is not in session. Any agreement under Section 233(e) of the Act must be transmitted to both Houses of Congress and the Clerk of the House or the Secretary of the Senate if either House is not in session. The document must include a determination by the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration on the impact on the actuarial balance of the social security system over a 75-year period. The agreement must result in a net reduction in the actuarial balance of the social security system over a 75-year period, equal to at least 0.005 percent of the present value of taxable payroll. The actuarial balance is the difference between the adjusted summarized income rate and the adjusted summarized cost rate over a specific period. The actuarial balance is the difference between the adjusted summarized income rate and the adjusted summarized cost rate over a period. The taxable payroll is the total wages and self-employment income to be paid and derived during that period. The adjusted summarized income rate is the ratio of the trust fund balance at the beginning of the period expressed as a percentage. The adjusted summarized income rate and adjusted summarized cost rate are defined as the ratios of trust fund balance, total income from taxes, and cost over a period to the taxable payroll. The term 'trust fund balance' refers to the combined balance of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. 'Income from taxes' is defined as the amounts deposited in the Trust Funds as appropriations during a specific period. During a period, 'income from taxes' refers to amounts deposited in the Trust Funds based on taxes under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. 'Cost' in the same period includes disbursements from the Trust Funds, such as benefit payments and special monthly payments to certain uninsured individuals. The term 'cost' refers to disbursements from the Trust Funds during a period, including benefit payments, special monthly payments to uninsured individuals with 3 or more quarters of coverage, administrative expenses, net transfers to the Railroad Retirement program, and payments for vocational rehabilitation services for disabled beneficiaries. The retirement program includes payments for vocational rehabilitation services for disabled beneficiaries and excludes special monthly payments to certain uninsured persons. The term 'target trust fund balance' is defined as the balance necessary to support an OASDI trust fund ratio of 100 percent for the year following a 75-year period. The Chief Actuary determines the trust fund balance needed to support a 100 percent OASDI trust fund ratio. The agreement will not take effect if certain conditions are met within a 60-day period. The Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund's annual report under section 201 states that an agreement will not be enforced if a bill disapproving it is passed within 60 days. The Chief Actuary's determination regarding the actuarial balance for a 75-year period is crucial for agreements under this section. The agreement under this section will only take effect if there is a net reduction in the actuarial balance of the social security system for a 75-year period, equal to at least 0.005 percent of the present value of taxable payroll. Additionally, a bill approving the agreement must be enacted into law within 60 days to enforce it. Additionally, a bill approving the agreement must be enacted into law within 60 days to enforce it. Congress has the power to approve or disapprove resolutions related to the agreement. The rules of each House apply to disapproval and approval resolutions, superseding other rules if inconsistent. Each House has the constitutional right to change its rules regarding procedures. During a 60-day period, each House of Congress can consider a bill for disapproval or approval of an agreement under certain rules. The majority or minority leader can offer the bill as a matter of highest privilege. For consideration of a bill providing solely for approval or disapproval of an agreement, the agreement cannot be amended after transmittal to each House of Congress. The effective date of this subsection applies to agreements establishing totalization arrangements under section 233 of the Social Security Act. The amendment made by this subsection applies to totalization arrangements transmitted to Congress after the enactment of this Act, regardless of previous agreements under section 233 of the Social Security Act. The agreement under section 233 of the Social Security Act, signed in June 2004 and transmitted to Congress after September 1, 2007, is part of totalization arrangements between the US and another country. The agreement under section 233 of the Social Security Act, signed in June 2004 and transmitted to Congress after September 1, 2007, shall be deemed not to have entered into force as of the date of the enactment of this Act and shall enter into force only as provided in section 233(e) of the Act. The Act amended the agreement under section 233 of the Social Security Act, stating that it will enter into force only after the President transmits a report to Congress in support of the agreement meeting certain requirements. Additionally, biennial reports to Congress regarding the ongoing operation of Totalization Agreements are required. "Biennial Oversight Reports are required for the ongoing operation of Totalization Agreements." The Commissioner of Social Security must submit biennial reports to Congress evaluating the operation of Totalization Agreements, including the impact on benefit costs under the social security system. The biennial reports to Congress must include information on the change in benefit costs and contributions under the social security system due to Totalization Agreements, as well as details on fraudulent receipt of benefits and perceived problems with the system. The biennial reports to Congress must include information on potential fraudulent receipt of benefits, problems with data integrity, and demographic trends affecting social security systems under Totalization Agreements. The Commissioner of Social Security must submit an initial report by December 31, 2008, containing information on demographic trends that may impact future costs to social security systems under Totalization Agreements. SEC. 203. SUSPENSION OF BENEFITS FOR INDIVIDUALS REMOVED FROM THE UNITED STATES. Section 202(n)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to state that no lump sum death payment shall be made to an individual after being notified of their removal from the United States by the Commissioner of Social Security, Attorney General, or Secretary of Homeland Security. The amendments to Section 202(n)(1) of the Social Security Act specify that no lump sum death payment will be made to an individual after being notified of their removal from the United States by the Commissioner of Social Security, Attorney General, or Secretary of Homeland Security. This applies to individuals notified of their removal after the twelfth month following the enactment of the Act.
